Table 1 Direct alkenylation of 2-substituted azaarenes with carbonyls via CH bond activation using iron-based metal-organic framework Fe3O(BPDC)3 as an efficient heterogeneous catalyst Hang T. Dang Thien N. Lieu Thanh Truong ⁎ Nam T.S. Phan ⁎ Department of Chemical Engineering, HCMC University of Technology, VNU-HCM, 268 Ly Thuong Kiet, District 10, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam Department of Chemical Engineering HCMC University of Technology VNU-HCM 268 Ly Thuong Kiet District 10 Ho Chi Minh City Viet Nam ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract A porous crystalline metal-organic framework Fe3O(BPDC)3 was synthesized from the reaction of biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid and iron(III) chloride hexahydrate by a solvothermal method in the presence of acetic acid, and was characterized by using a variety of different techniques. The Fe3O(BPDC)3 could be used as an efficient heterogeneous catalyst in the synthesis of 2-alkenylazaarenes using the direct alkenylation of 2-substituted azaarenes with carbonyls via CH bond activation. The presence of acetic acid as a co-catalyst accelerated the transformation significantly. The Fe3O(BPDC)3 exhibited better performance in this transformation then other MOFs such as Fe3O(BDC)3, Cu2(OBA)2(BPY), Cu2(BDC)2(DABCO), Ni2(BDC)2(DABCO), Zn-MOF-74, and Cu2(NDC)2(DABCO). The Fe3O(BPDC)3 also exhibited higher catalytic activity than that of several homogeneous catalysts such as FeCl2, FeCl3, CuCl2, Zn(OAc)2, Zn(NO3)2, and Ni(OAc)2. The Fe3O(BPDC)3 catalyst could be recovered and reused several times in the synthesis of 2-alkenylazaarenes without a significant degradation in catalytic activity. To the best of our knowledge, 2-alkenylazaarenes was not previously synthesized via the direct alkenylation of 2-substituted azaarenes with carbonyls using heterogeneous catalysts. Keywords Metal-organic framework Alkenylation Fe3O(BPDC)3 Heterogeneous catalyst 2-substituted azaarenes 1 Introduction 2-Alkenylazaarenes have emerged as ubiquitous structural motifs found in many bioactive natural products, pharmaceuticals, and agrochemicals, and as important precursors used in the synthesis of numerous heterocycles [1–5]. These structures were originally synthesized by the condensation of 2-methylazaarenes and aldehydes using stoichiometric amounts of strong acids or bases [6–8]. Transition metal-catalyzed cross-coupling reactions via direct CH activation would offer more environmentally benign protocols for the synthesis of these heterocycles [9,10]. Wu and co-workers previously reported the direct coupling of quinoline-N-oxides with olefin derivatives to give the corresponding 2-alkenylated quinolines using palladium acetate as catalyst [11]. Hiyama and co-workers pointed out that the C-2 selective direct alkenylation of pyridine derivatives could be achieved with a catalyst system consisting of nickel and diorganozinc compounds as Lewis acid [12]. Charette and co-workers synthesized alkenyl pyridines via a direct CH alkenylation of N-iminopyridinium ylides using several different copper sources as catalyst [13]. Huang and co-workers developed an iron acetate-catalyzed direct alkenylation of 2-substituted azaarenes with N-sulfonyl aldimines via CH bond activation [14]. Recently, Zou and co-workers demonstrated the first example of the C(sp3)-H functionalization of methyl azaarenes with carbonyl compounds to form 2-alkenylazaarenes in the presence of iron acetate and trifluoroacetic acid as catalyst system [15]. To achieve greener approaches for the direct alkenylation of 2-substituted azaarenes in the synthesis of 2-alkenylazaarenes, heterogeneous catalysts should be used for the transformation. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted tremendous interest over the last decade for their potential applications in many fields, ranging from gas storage to catalysis [16–23]. In contrast with conventional crystalline porous solids, properties of MOFs could be finely tuned by changing different organic bridging ligands as well as different metal cations of diverse oxidation states and coordination geometries [16,17,24–32]. Although the application of MOFs in catalysis is a young research area, relevant publications have increased dramatically in the last few years [23,33–38]. In MOFs, the catalysis could be based on the metal connecting points or at the ligands forming the walls being arranged in predictable and tunable manner due to the nature of these frameworks [34,39–45]. Indeed, numerous carbon-carbon [37,46–55] and carbon-heteroatom forming transformations [56–63] have been performed using MOF-based catalysts. Iron-based metal-organic frameworks were previously synthesized and employed as heterogeneous catalysts for organic transformations [64–68]. In this paper, we would like to present the direct alkenylation of 2-substituted azaarenes with carbonyls via CH bond activation to produce 2-alkenylazaarenes using the iron-based metal-organic framework Fe3O(BPDC)3 as a recyclable heterogeneous catalyst. To the best of our knowledge, 2-alkenylazaarenes was not previously synthesized via the direct alkenylation transformation using heterogeneous catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and instrumentation All organic and inorganic chemicals were purchased from Sigma–Aldrich, Acros/Fisher Scientific, and Merck, and were used as received. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) analysis were performed using a D8 Advance Bruker powder diffractometer with a Cu Kα radiation source. Surface areas and pore size distribution of the Fe3O(BPDC)3 catalyst were achieved via nitrogen physisorption measurements on a Micromeritics 2020 volumetric adsorption analyzer system. Fe-MOF samples were heated under vacuum at 150°C for 5h prior to the measurement. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out on a Netzsch Thermoanalyzer STA 409 with a heating rate of 10°C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere. Elemental analysis of the Fe-MOF was conducted on an AA-6800 Shimadzu using atomic absorption spectrophotometry (AAS) method. A Hitachi S-4800 Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) was used to achieve SEM images. A JEOL JEM 1400 Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM) was employed to obtain TEM image. A Nicolet 6700 was used for Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) analysis, with samples being dispersed on potassium bromide pallets. Reaction yield was monitored by gas chromatographic (GC) analysis on an FID Shimadzu GC 2010-Plus with a SPB-5 column (length=30m, inner diameter=0.25 mm, and film thickness=0.25μm). In the GC temperature program, the sample of the reaction was held at 120°C for 0.5min; heated from 120 to 130°C at 40°C/min; held at 130°C for 1min; heated from 130 to 280°C at 40°C/min; and finally held at 280°C for 4.5min. Reaction yield was calculated based on a series of (E)-2-styrylquinoline standard solutions, using diphenyl ether as an internal standard. A Shimadzu GCMS-QP2010Ultra with a ZB-5MS column (length=30m, inner diameter=0.25mm, and film thickness=0.25 μm) was used for GC–MS analysis. In the GC–MS temperature program, the sample was held samples at 50°C for 2min; heated from 50 to 280°C at 10°C/min and held at 280°C for 10min. A Bruker AV-500 spectrometer was employed for 1H NMR and 13C NMR analysis 2.2 Synthesis of the metal-organic framework Fe3O(BPDC)3 The Fe3O(BPDC)3 was synthesized from the reaction of biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid and iron(III) chloride hexahydrate by a solvothermal method in the presence of acetic acid. In a typical synthesis, a mixture of FeCl3·6H2O (1.08g, 4.0mmol), H2BPDC (H2BPDC=biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid; 0.48g, 2.0mmol) was dissolved in DMF (DMF=N,N′-dimethylformamide; 114ml) containg acetic acid (CH3COOH; 2.4ml, 42mmol). The solution was then distributed in twenty four 20-ml vials. The vials were tightly capped and heated at 120°C in an isothermal oven for 48h. After unassisted cooling the vials to room temperature, the crystals were separated by decantation, and washed with DMF (3×10ml). Dichloromethane (3×10ml) was used for solvent exchange at room temperature. The Fe-MOF was then heated at 150°C for 6h under vacuum, yielding 0.428g of the Fe3O(BPDC)3 as orange crystals (71% based on biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid). 2.3 Catalytic studies In a typical experiment, Fe3O(BPDC)3 catalyst (0.012g, 10mol%) was added to the 10ml vial containing a solution of 2-methylquinoline (0.057g, 0.4mmol), acetic acid (0.002g, 10mol%), benzaldehyde (0.064g, 0.6mmol) and diphenyl ether (0.068g, 0.4mmol) as an internal standard in toluene (1ml). The catalyst amount was calculated with respect to the iron/2-methylquinoline molar ratio and the measured AAS value of Fe3O(BPDC)3 (See Supporting Information). Then reaction mixture was filled with argon and magnetically stirred for 24h at 120°C. Reaction yield was monitored by withdrawing aliquots from the reaction mixture, quenching with Na2CO3 solution (1ml). The organic components were then extracted into ethyl acetate (3ml), dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, and analyzed by GC with reference to diphenyl ether. The combined organic layers were concentrated under reduced pressure. The resulting residue was purified by recrystalization in ethanol and water to afford (E)-2-styrylquinoline. The product identity was further confirmed by GC–MS, 1H NMR, and 13C NMR. To investigate the recyclability of the Fe3O(BPDC)3, the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by simple centrifugation, washed with copious amounts of toluene, dichloromethane, then activated under vacuum at 150°C for 3h, and reused under identical conditions. 3 Results and discussion The iron-based metal-organicframework Fe3O(BPDC)3 was synthesized according to a slightly modified literature procedure [69], and was characterized by several techniques, including XRD, SEM, TEM, TGA, FT-IR, AAS, and nitrogen physisorption measurements (Figs. S1–S5) (Fig. 1 ). The Fe3O(BPDC)3 was assessed for its catalytic activity in the direct alkenylation of 2-methylquinoline with benzaldehyde via CH bond activation to form (E)-2-styrylquinoline as the principal product (Scheme 1 ). Initial studies addressed the effect of temperature on the yield of (E)-2-styrylquinoline. The direct alkenylation reaction was carried out in toluene under argon for 24h, in the presence of 10mol% Fe3O(BPDC)3 catalyst, with 10mol% acetic acid as co-catalyst, at 2-methylquinoline concentration of 0.4M, using 2-methylquinoline:benzaldehyde molar ratio of 1:1.5, at room temperature, 60°C, 90°C, 100°C, 110°C, and 120°C, respectively. It was found that no reaction occurred at temperature lower than 60°C, with no trace amount of (E)-2-styrylquinoline being detected after 24h. The transformation occurred with difficulty at 90°C, affording only 16% yield. As expected, increasing the reaction temperature led to a significant enhancement in the yield of (E)-2-styrylquinoline. The reaction carried out at 100°C could proceed to 26% yield while 41% yield was observed for the case of 110°C. It was found that the yield of (E)-2-styrylquinoline could be improved to 58% for the reaction carried out at 120°C (Fig. 2 ). Indeed, in the first example of the C(sp3)-H functionalization of methyl azaarenes with carbonyl compounds to form 2-alkenylazaarenes using iron acetate and trifluoroacetic acid as catalyst system, Zou and co-workers also performed the transformation at 120°C [15]. Another factor that should be addressed for the Fe3O(BPDC)3-catalyzed direct alkenylation of 2-methylquinoline with benzaldehyde via CH bond activation to form (E)-2-styrylquinoline is the catalyst concentration. The direct alkenylation reaction was carried out at 120°C in toluene under argon for 24h, at 2-methylquinoline concentration of 0.4M, using 2-methylquinoline:benzaldehyde molar ratio of 1:1.5, with 10mol% acetic acid as co-catalyst, in the presence of 2.5mol%, 5mol%, 7.5mol%, 10mol%, 12.5mol%, and 15mol% Fe3O(BPDC)3 catalyst, respectively. The reaction using 2.5mol% catalyst proceeded with difficulty with 38% yield. Increasing the catalyst concentration led to an enhancement in the formation of (E)-2-styrylquinoline when 42% yield was observed. This value could be improved to 58% for the reaction using 10mol% Fe3O(BPDC)3 catalyst. It was found that 71% yield of (E)-2-styrylquinoline could be achieved for the transformation in the presence of 15mol% Fe3O(BPDC)3 catalyst. It should be noted that 26% yield of (E)-2-styrylquinoline was detected in the absence of Fe3O(BPDC)3 catalyst. Without using both Fe3O(BPDC)3 as catalyst and acetic acid as co-catalyst, the reaction afforded 19% yield after 24h (Fig. 3 ). These observations were consistent with those previously reported by Zou and co-workers, in which 29% and 18% yields were detected after 24h for the reaction using 10mol% trifluoroacetic acid in the absence of iron acetate, and for the control reaction carried out in the absence of both iron acetate and trifluoroacetic acid, respectively [15]. The solvent could exhibit a significant impact on the reaction rate for organic transformations carried out in the presence of solid catalysts, depending on the nature of the catalyst [70,71]. It was therefore decided to investigate the effect of different solvents on the direct alkenylation of 2-methylquinoline with benzaldehyde via CH bond activation to form (E)-2-styrylquinoline using Fe3O(BPDC)3 catalyst. The direct alkenylation reaction was carried out at 120°C under argon for 24h, in the presence of 10mol% Fe3O(BPDC)3 catalyst, with 10mol% acetic acid as co-catalyst, at 2-methylquinoline concentration of 0.4M, using 2-methylquinoline:benzaldehyde molar ratio of 1:1.5, in toluene, chlorobenzene, diglyme, DMSO, p-xylene, and mesitylene as solvent, respectively. The Fe3O(BPDC)3-catalyzed direct alkenylation of 2-methylquinoline with benzaldehyde proceeded with difficulty in DMSO, affording only 14% yield of (E)-2-styrylquinoline after 24h. The reaction carried out in diglyme produced the desired product in a yield of 38% after 24h, while 52% yield was observed for the case of chlorobenzene. Using mesitylene and p-xylene as solvent, (E)-2-styrylquinoline was produced in a yield of 47% and 51%, respectively, after 24h. Among these solvents, toluene exhibited the best performance, with 58% yield of (E)-2-styrylquinoline being achieved after 24h (Fig. 4 ). Moreover, it was also observed that the reactant concentration affected the Fe3O(BPDC)3-catalyzed direct alkenylation of 2-methylquinoline with benzaldehyde, and best yield was obtained at 2-methylquinoline concentration of 0.4M. With these results in mind, we then decided to investigate the effect of 2-methylquinoline:benzaldehyde molar ratio on the formation of (E)-2-styrylquinoline in the Fe3O(BPDC)3-catalyzed direct alkenylation of 2-methylquinoline with benzaldehyde via CH bond activation. The direct alkenylation reaction was carried out in toluene at 120°C under argon for 24h, in the presence of 10mol% Fe3O(BPDC)3 catalyst, with 10mol% acetic acid as co-catalyst, at 2-methylquinoline concentration of 0.4M, using 2-methylquinoline:benzaldehyde molar ratio of 1:1, 1:1.25, 1:1.5, 1:1.75, and 1:2, respectively. It was found that 2-methylquinoline:benzaldehyde molar ratio exhibited a significant effect on the yield of (E)-2-styrylquinoline. Using 1 equivalent of benzaldehyde, the direct alkenylation reaction proceeded with difficulty, though 47% yield was still obtained after 24h. The increase in the amount of benzaldehyde led to an enhancement in the yield of the desired product. The Fe3O(BPDC)3-catalyzed direct alkenylation reaction could proceed to 51% yield after 24h with 1.25 equivalents of benzaldehyde, while 58% yield was observed after 24h for the reaction using 1.5 equivalents of benzaldehyde. The yield of (E)-2-styrylquinoline could be improved to 60% after 24h when 1.75 equivalents of benzaldehyde was employed for the transformation. It was observed that 75% yield (E)-2-styrylquinoline was achieved after 24h for the reaction using 2 equivalents of benzaldehyde (Fig. 5 ). In the first example of the iron-catalyzed C(sp3)-H functionalization of methyl azaarenes with carbonyl compounds to form 2-alkenylazaarenes, Zou and co-workers pointed out that the transformation was significantly accelerated by the addition of a catalytic amount of a Brønsted acid such as methanesulfonic acid, triflic acid, 4-toluenesulfonic acid, acetic acid, or trifluoroacetic acid as a co-catalyst, and that trifluoroacetic acid exhibited the best performance [15]. We therefore decided to investigate the effect of different acid on the formation of (E)-2-styrylquinoline in the Fe3O(BPDC)3-catalyzed direct alkenylation of 2-methylquinoline with benzaldehyde via C-H bond activation. The direct alkenylation reaction was carried out in toluene at 120°C under argon for 24h, in the presence of 10mol% Fe3O(BPDC)3 catalyst, at 2-methylquinoline concentration of 0.4M, using 2-methylquinoline:benzaldehyde molar ratio of 1:2, with 10mol% trifluoroacetic, acetic acid, benzoic acid, phenyl propiolic acid, fumaric acid, pentanoic acid, benzoylformic acid, cinnamic acid, pivalic acid, respectively, as co-catalyst. It was found that the Fe3O(BPDC)3-catalyzed direct alkenylation of 2-methylquinoline with benzaldehyde could proceed to 68% yield of (E)-2-styrylquinoline in the absence of the Brønsted acid co-catalyst. Indeed, Zou and co-workers previously demonstrated that the same transformation could afford 66% yield without using the Brønsted acid co-catalyst [15]. Under tested conditions, reaction using only Fe-MOFs catalyst resulted in 51% conversion. However, from experimental point of view, it should be noted that benzaldehyde could be oxidized to benzoic acid, and this Brønsted acid, even in trace amount, could work as the co-catalyst for the transformation. Trifluoroacetic acid was found to be not suitable for the direct alkenylation using Fe3O(BPDC)3 catalyst as the Fe-MOF was decomposed during the course of the reaction. Among these co-catalysts, acetic acid and benzoic acid exhibited the best performance, with 75% yield of (E)-2-styrylquinoline being achieved after 24h (Fig. 6 ). To further elucidate the actual active sites, a control reaction was carried out using pyridine as a catalyst poison. In the first experiment, the Fe3O(BPDC)3 catalyst was soaked in pyridine for 6h at room temperature. These Fe-MOF samples were then used as catalyst under identical conditions. The experimental results showed that Fe-MOF soaked in pyridine 6h prior to use significantly retarded the reaction with only 40% conversion was achieved. In second experiment, Cu-MOF soaked with pyridine in 6h was activated at 160°C to remove part of adsorbed pyridine and then employed as catalyst for identical reaction. Noticeably, up to 52% conversion was obtained. The fact that pyridine as catalyst poison exhibited a profound impact on reaction progress confirming the role of iron sites in the transformation. In addition, reactions at lower concentration (0.3M) and reactions with magnitude of three times greater scale afforded 68 and 70% conversion, respectively. Though it is likely that effect of mass transportation is negligible, profound studies are still needed (Fig. 7 ). As the direct alkenylation of 2-methylquinoline with benzaldehyde via CH bond activation to form (E)-2-styrylquinoline using Fe3O(BPDC)3 catalyst was performed in liquid phase, the possibility that some of catalytically active sites on the solid Fe-MOF could migrate into the solution during the course of the reaction should be addressed. In several cases, although a solid catalyst was employed, the transformation would not proceed under real heterogeneous catalysis conditions due to the leaching problem [71]. In order to check if active iron species dissolved from the solid Fe3O(BPDC)3 catalyst, if any, contributed significantly to the formation of (E)-2-styrylquinoline via the direct alkenylation reaction, a control experiment was carried out using a simple centrifugation during the course of the reaction. The direct alkenylation reaction was carried out in toluene at 120°C under argon for 24h, in the presence of 10mol% Fe3O(BPDC)3 catalyst, at 2-methylquinoline concentration of 0.4M, using 2-methylquinoline:benzaldehyde molar ratio of 1:2, with 10mol% acetic acid as co-catalyst. After 8h reaction time with 35% yield of (E)-2-styrylquinoline being detected, the solid Fe3O(BPDC)3 was separated from the reaction mixture by centrifugation. The reaction solution was then transferred to a new reactor vessel, and stirred for an additional 16h at 120°C under argon. It should be noted that only Fe3O(BPDC)3 was separated by the centrifugation, and acetic acid was still in the liquid phase. It was found that 46% yield of (E)-2-styrylquinoline was obtained under this condition (Fig. 8 ). As mentioned earlier, the direct alkenylation reaction could still proceed in the presence of only acetic acid as catalyst, though significantly lower yield of the desired product was detected. Furthermore, ICP-MS of reaction filtrate was also conducted and the results showed <3ppm of iron. It was therefore proposed that the contribution of leached active iron species to the formation of (E)-2-styrylquinoline, if any, was negligible. To highlight the advantages of using the Fe3O(BPDC)3 as catalyst for the direct alkenylation of 2-methylquinoline with benzaldehyde via CH bond activation to form (E)-2-styrylquinoline, the catalytic activity of the Fe3O(BPDC)3 was compared with that of other MOFs, including Fe3O(BDC)3, Cu2(OBA)2(BPY), Cu2(BDC)2(DABCO), Ni2(BDC)2(DABCO), Zn-MOF-74, and Cu2(NDC)2(DABCO). These MOFs were synthesized by solvothermal method and characterized according to literature procedures [38,72–77]. The direct alkenylation reaction was carried out in toluene at 120°C under argon for 24h, in the presence of 10mol% catalyst, at 2-methylquinoline concentration of 0.4M, using 2-methylquinoline:benzaldehyde molar ratio of 1:2, with 10mol% acetic acid as co-catalyst. The Fe3O(BDC)3-catalyzed alkenylation reaction could proceed to 50% yield of (E)-2-styrylquinoline after 24h, while 75% yield was achieved for that using Fe3O(BPDC)3 catalyst. This observation could be rationalized based on the fact that Fe3O(BPDC)3 possessed larger pore windows and higher surface areas than those of Fe3O(BDC)3. Other MOFs also exhibited less catalytic activity than Fe3O(BDC)3 in this transformation. The reaction using Cu2(BDC)2(DABCO) afforded 49% yield of (E)-2-styrylquinoline after 24h, while 34% yield was detected for the case of Cu2(NDC)2(DABCO). The zinc-based MOFs Zn-MOF-74 offered similar catalytic activity to Fe3O(BDC)3, with 50% yield of the desired product being obtained after 24h. Among these MOFs, Ni2(BDC)2(DABCO) exhibited lowest activity for the transformation, producing (E)-2-styrylquinoline in a yield of only 22% after 24h (Fig. 9 ). In addition, the cavity size according to the Fe3O(BDC)3 structure is about 7Å (Table S1) while the kinetic diameters of aromatic reactant and product are calculated to be 5.2°A and 11.7°A, respectively [78,79]. Furthermore, pore flexibility in MOFs upon temperature and guest molecules has been previously reported [80]. Therefore, further spectroscopic studies are still needed to confirm where the reactions take place (Fig. 10 ). The catalytic activity of Fe3O(BPDC)3 in the direct alkenylation of 2-methylquinoline with benzaldehyde via CH bond activation to form (E)-2-styrylquinoline was also compared with that of other homogeneous catalysts, including FeCl2, FeCl3, CuCl2, Zn(OAc)2, Zn(NO3)2, Ni(OAc)2, and biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid, the organic linker used to synthesize Fe3O(BPDC)3. The direct alkenylation reaction was carried out in toluene at 120°C under argon for 24h, in the presence of 10mol% catalyst, at 2-methylquinoline concentration of 0.4M, using 2-methylquinoline:benzaldehyde molar ratio of 1:2, with 10mol% acetic acid as co-catalyst. It was observed that FeCl3, the inorganic component used to prepare Fe3O(BPDC)3, exhibited lower catalytic activity than Fe3O(BPDC)3, producing (E)-2-styrylquinoline in a yield of 45% after 24h. The reaction using FeCl2 catalyst could proceed to 66% yield of the desired product after 24h. Zn(OAc)2 was found to be more active than FeCl2 in this transformation, affording 74% yield after 24h. Ni(OAc)2 should not be used as catalyst for the direct alkenylation reaction, with only 41% yield of (E)-2-styrylquinoline being observed after 24h. It was also found that the reaction using biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid, the organic linker used to synthesize Fe3O(BPDC)3, as catalyst could proceed to 38% yield after 24h. Reactions using other common Lewis (AlCl3, ZnO, and Zeolite X) and Bronted acids (p-toluensulfonic acid) afforded <55% conversion. This again confirmed the important organometallic property of iron metal sites. The fact that Fe3O(BPDC)3 could offer better performance than several homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts in the direct alkenylation of 2-methylquinoline with benzaldehyde was therefore of advantages. To further explore the advantages of using the Fe3O(BPDC)3 as catalyst in the direct alkenylation of 2-methylquinoline with benzaldehyde via CH bond activation to form (E)-2-styrylquinoline, we then decided to investigate the reusability of this Fe-MOF catalyst. When using a solid catalyst for organic reactions, it is expected that the catalyst can be recovered and reused many times before it eventually deactivates completely. The Fe3O(BPDC)3 was therefore explored for recoverability and reusability in the direct alkenylation of 2-methylquinoline with benzaldehyde over 7 successive runs, by repeatedly separating the Fe-MOF catalyst from the reaction mixture, washing it and then reusing it. During the research, it was found that increasing the Fe3O(BPDC)3 catalyst concentration to 15mol% significantly enhanced the formation of (E)-2-styrylquinoline, affording up to 91% yield after 24h. It was therefore decided to employed 15mol% catalyst for the catalytic recycling studies. The direct alkenylation reaction was carried out in toluene at 120°C under argon for 24h, in the presence of 15mol% Fe3O(BPDC)3 catalyst, at 2-methylquinoline concentration of 0.4M, using 2-methylquinoline:benzaldehyde molar ratio of 1:2, with 10mol% acetic acid as co-catalyst. After 24h reaction time with 91% yield of (E)-2-styrylquinoline being achieved, the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by simple centrifugation, washed with copious amounts of dichloromethane to remove any physisorbed reagents, activated under vacuum at 150°C for 3h. The recovered Fe3O(BPDC)3 catalyst was then reused in further experiment under identical conditions to those of the first run. Experimental indicated that the Fe-MOF catalyst could be recovered and reused many times in the direct alkenylation of 2-methylquinoline with benzaldehyde without a significant degradation in catalytic activity. Indeed, 89% yield of (E)-2-styrylquinoline was still achieved in the 7th run (Fig. 11 ). Moreover, the structure of the Fe3O(BPDC)3 catalyst could be maintained during the course of the transformation, as shown by XRD (Fig. 12 ) and FT-IR (Fig. 13 ) results of the recovered catalyst. We also performed the synthesis of several styrylquinolines containing different substituents via the direct alkenylation in the presence of Fe3O(BPDC)3 catalyst. In the first experiment series, we carried out the direct alkenylation of 2-methylquinoline with different benzaldehydes, including benzaldehyde, 2-bromobenzaldehyde, 4-nitrobenzaldehyde, 4-(dimethylamino)benzaldehyde, 4-methylbenzaldehyde, 4-methoxybenzaldehyde, 3,4-dimethoxybenzaldehyde, and 4-phenoxybenzaldehyde. The direct alkenylation reaction was carried out in toluene at 120°C under argon for 24h, in the presence of 15mol% Fe3O(BPDC)3 catalyst, at 2-methylquinoline concentration of 0.4M, using 2-methylquinoline:benzaldehyde molar ratio of 1:2, with 10mol% acetic acid as co-catalyst. All products were isolated and their purity and identity were confirmed by NMR (See Supporting information). (E)-2-styrylquinoline was achieved in an isolated yield of 88%. It was found that the presence of an electron-withdrawing substituent on the benzene ring in benzaldehyde accelerated the transformation. The Fe3O(BPDC)3-catalyzed direct alkenylation of 2-methylquinoline with 2-bromobenzaldehyde and 4-nitrobenzaldehyde produced (E)-2-(2-bromostyryl)quinoline and (E)-2-(4-nitrostyryl)quinoline in isolated yields of 95% and 92%, respectively. Benzaldehydes containing electron-donating substituents were found to be less reactive towards the direct alkenylation with 2-methylquinolin. However, by increasing the reaction time, (E)-N,N-dimethyl-4-(2-(quinolin-2-yl)vinyl)benzenamine could be produced with 75% isolated yield. Similarly, (E)-2-(4-methylstyryl)quinoline, (E)-2-(4-methoxystyryl)quinoline, and (E)-2-(3,4-dimethoxystyryl)quinoline could be achieved in 86%, 90%, and 85% isolated yields, respectively. 2-Methylquinoxaline were found to be less reactive than 2-methylquinoline, though 66% yield of (E)-2-styrylquinoxaline was still obtained (Table 1 ). 4 Conclusions In summary, the porous crystalline Fe3O(BPDC)3 was synthesized from the reaction of biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid and iron(III) chloride hexahydrate by a solvothermal method in the presence of acetic acid. The Fe-MOF could be used as an efficient heterogeneous catalyst for the direct alkenylation of 2-substituted azaarenes with carbonyls via CH bond activation to produce 2-alkenylazaarenes. The presence of acetic acid as a co-catalyst accelerated the transformation significantly. The Fe3O(BPDC)3 exhibited higher catalytic activity in the direct alkenylation reaction than that of other MOFs such as Fe3O(BDC)3, Cu2(OBA)2(BPY), Cu2(BDC)2(DABCO), Ni2(BDC)2(DABCO), Zn-MOF-74, and Cu2(NDC)2(DABCO). The Fe3O(BPDC)3 also offered better performance in this transformation than several homogeneous catalysts such as FeCl2, FeCl3, CuCl2, Zn(OAc)2, Zn(NO3)2, Ni(OAc)2, and biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid. The Fe3O(BPDC)3 catalyst could be recovered and reused several times in the direct alkenylation of 2-substituted azaarenes with carbonyls via CH bond activation to produce 2-alkenylazaarenes without a significant degradation in catalytic activity. The fact that 2-alkenylazaarenes could be produced using a recyclable heterogeneous catalyst would be interested to the chemical industry. coredata.dc:description: A porous crystalline metal-organic framework Fe3O(BPDC)3 was synthesized from the reaction of biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid and iron(III) chloride hexahydrate by a solvothermal method in the presence of acetic acid, and was characterized by using a variety of different techniques. The Fe3O(BPDC)3 could be used as an efficient heterogeneous catalyst in the synthesis of 2-alkenylazaarenes using the direct alkenylation of 2-substituted azaarenes with carbonyls via CH bond activation. The presence of acetic acid as a co-catalyst accelerated the transformation significantly. The Fe3O(BPDC)3 exhibited better performance in this transformation then other MOFs such as Fe3O(BDC)3, Cu2(OBA)2(BPY), Cu2(BDC)2(DABCO), Ni2(BDC)2(DABCO), Zn-MOF-74, and Cu2(NDC)2(DABCO). The Fe3O(BPDC)3 also exhibited higher catalytic activity than that of several homogeneous catalysts such as FeCl2, FeCl3, CuCl2, Zn(OAc)2, Zn(NO3)2, and Ni(OAc)2. The Fe3O(BPDC)3 catalyst could be recovered and reused several times in the synthesis of 2-alkenylazaarenes without a significant degradation in catalytic activity. To the best of our knowledge, 2-alkenylazaarenes was not previously synthesized via the direct alkenylation of 2-substituted azaarenes with carbonyls using heterogeneous catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Direct alkenylation of 2-substituted azaarenes with carbonyls via CH bond activation using iron-based metal-organic framework Fe3O(BPDC)3 as an efficient heterogeneous catalyst
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
